data.text: The decline in hours worked was particularly large in 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic, although this decline is expected to be temporary. During the crisis, some euro area firms chose to reduce hours per worker to avoid job losses 2/3

Employees in the euro area worked on average about 100 hours less in 2019 than in 1995. This relates to changes in labour regulations, shifts towards the service sector and increases in the female workforce and related part-time jobs https://t.co/EQwAevEsUo #EconomicBulletin 1/3 https://t.co/eUtKtXvbtq

I fully understand people’s concerns about low interest rates, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos. But you need to look at all effects our policies have, including the impact on economic growth and jobs. You need to find the right balance https://t.co/LouhPcGKth https://t.co/F0mUI06171

Europe is recovering more rapidly than we had anticipated, President @Lagarde tells @DM_Rubenstein on @BloombergTV. It is now a question of making sure that our economies bounce back in a way that positions them to be more digital and greener https://t.co/j9xH6GtYgE https://t.co/LCkuEBRxZn
The winning paper will be announced by President @Lagarde at the #ECBForum on 29 September. Stay tuned! https://t.co/s8XI0JroQh

“Exciting, impressive and inspiring” is how this year’s young economists’ competition finalists describe their discussion with Executive Board members Philip R. Lane and @Isabel_Schnabel about the relevance of academic analysis for policymaking institutions such as the ECB. https://t.co/7C8kORA7I7

Current low real yields may be less puzzling than they may appear at first sight, explains Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel in a speech at today’s Bond Market Contact Group meeting.

Read her full speech https://t.co/w2gMxSvSsK https://t.co/ztOLKzx6gF

Congratulations to our colleague Isabel Vansteenkiste (@isabelsabine), who will take the helm of the ECB’s International and European Relations department from 1 November 2021.

We look forward to working together with Isabel in her new role! https://t.co/LKNStCWtxe

But the economy is not yet doing as well as it can.

More than two million fewer people are employed compared to before the pandemic.

In some sectors, shortages of materials and equipment hold back production.

Read more https://t.co/PGRoRRKKmL

4/4 https://t.co/gPI0h0Uamk

The economic recovery is advancing.

70% of adult Europeans are fully vaccinated, and the economy has largely reopened. A better jobs market holds out the prospect of higher incomes and greater spending

3/4 https://t.co/0WF64ALiCN

Favourable financing conditions support people, companies and the public sector, so that the economy can continue its recovery

2/4 https://t.co/LU3ceNjv6N

Today’s monetary policy statement at a glance – a thread:

Our monetary policy continues to support the economy.

Financing conditions are favourable and the outlook for inflation has improved slightly. This allows for a moderately lower pace of asset purchases 

1/4 https://t.co/u0CTLRwWah
ECB staff macroeconomic projections for the euro area (September 2021) https://t.co/Az8ogrX2Ya https://t.co/dC9rQheXEX

President @Lagarde has just presented the Governing Council’s monetary policy statement, formerly known as the introductory statement.

Read the statement https://t.co/G0isuxXcL6
President @Lagarde introduces the inflation outlook for the euro area. https://t.co/vbFUcqJBYQ
President Christine @Lagarde introduces the economic growth outlook for the euro area. https://t.co/d6LPYAfOx7
Watch the ECB press conference live: President Christine @Lagarde explains today’s monetary policy decisions https://t.co/jFEL8jw6DF
Coming up in 15 minutes: watch live as President Christine @Lagarde explains the latest monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/Yqkk6qr90c
Press release: Monetary policy decisions https://t.co/nF1ljpni7M

Enria: We need to move forward and make the most of the opportunities that are already available in the current European legislative framework. Banks can play a fundamental role here by relying more on branches and the free provision of services 3/3

Enria: European banks need to compete globally with banks that have a much deeper and more efficient domestic markets. This is made even harder by the fact that the European market remains deeply segmented along national lines for many banking products and services 2/3

(THREAD) Completing the banking union will take time despite the progress already made, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. We cannot stand by while complex political negotiations play out https://t.co/ZpjNDuNCyX 1/3 https://t.co/rsa7cHAjMJ
Later today: watch live as ECB President Christine @Lagarde explains the latest monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/2gI8ONCGKZ

We should not postpone the final leg of Basel III reforms any further, says Supervisory Board member Elizabeth McCaul. They will not prevent banks from supporting the recovery https://t.co/qhs3aElgUY https://t.co/t4IIoPc0cM

European banks have weathered this crisis relatively well, thanks in part to regulatory changes made since the global financial crisis, says Supervisory Board member Kerstin af Jochnick. A number of risks still need to be addressed though https://t.co/6mTUHCsVfy https://t.co/NmOLD3ujaa
ECB-EBA letter on EU implementation of outstanding Basel III reforms https://t.co/iBKU3gmHKC

@Lagarde on what helped her most in her career:

I think it's love. That was most helpful to me.

Because the love that I received from parents, family, husbands, children, has given me the confidence to ignore some of the noise along the way. Confidence matters enormously

3/4

(THREAD) We are emerging from this pandemic with economies that have stabilised and are recovering, President Christine @Lagarde tells @wef’s @ProfKlausSchwab.

She adds that focused and targeted support is still needed for those sectors that have been badly hurt 1/4 https://t.co/rPRWIcR5I1
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (July 2021) https://t.co/e3BQtAucXf

While some of the economic fallout from the pandemic has been successfully dampened, minimising its structural impact in areas such as public debt and labour markets will now be key, Vice-President Luis de Guindos tells @elconfidencial in an interview https://t.co/OHHLf5EUt2 https://t.co/wCqCIrToTl

The existential threat posed by climate change implies that central banks must not stand on the sidelines in the fight against global warming, writes Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel in a contribution to @IMFNews’s Finance & Development Magazine https://t.co/nkJ7QEqHgN https://t.co/6ejvD8RWFA
Occasional Paper: Asset encumbrance in euro area banks - Analysing trends, drivers and prediction properties for individual bank crises https://t.co/P8lW0TJYeT

Banks have lent net €707 billion to euro area people and firms since March 2020. Over this period banks lent more money to households (+5.3%) and companies (+8.3%), supported by the measures to fight the pandemic. More statistics in our press release https://t.co/YpDGACIIzK https://t.co/gW2NJBtm29
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in July? How do they compare with June's figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/YpDGACIIzK https://t.co/aXszQhiVLo
Lane: In the autumn, we’ll have to work through what 2022 should look like. Asset purchases will continue after the PEPP, as we’ll have our asset purchase programme (APP) running 3/3
Lane: While growth in the second quarter came in well ahead of our projections, there are also headwinds, including from the Delta variant and some moderation in the world economy 2/3

(THREAD) Any adjustment we make to the pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP) within the pandemic period is within the philosophy of maintaining favourable financing conditions, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @Reuters in an interview https://t.co/Jp8eWq6VPK 1/3 https://t.co/yXDULLKvay
Occasional Paper: How useful is market information for the identification of G-SIBs? https://t.co/ZpBb6g72i9
Working Paper: Estimating Fed’s unconventional policy shocks https://t.co/NGNF3qyNBB

The rise in non-bank finance has likely broadened monetary policy transmission, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. But it has also created new risks for the conduct of monetary policy, requiring enhanced macroprudential policies for non-banks https://t.co/2E1ZZe88Zn https://t.co/t2UZeLa8Pb

Most banks still aren’t managing climate-related risks in line with our expectations, but they are becoming more aware of gaps and have drawn up action plans. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/2EuzRNXFF5 https://t.co/clrZj4qy3o

Our new approach to Pillar 2 guidance is based on the stress test results and tailored to each bank. It aims to provide more transparency and level the playing field. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/p9XTWvCiS9 https://t.co/h6M6E3e5GM

We asked banks about their IT and cyber risks. More work is needed on IT data quality management. IT security should remain a priority as attackers are increasingly targeting banks’ external service providers. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/Gx1zJN7yaG https://t.co/BeoohqUQwh

A look back at the decisions on dividends taken during the pandemic shows that our measures were effective. Banks that adapted their dividend distribution increased provisions and lending. Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/15K61lykEI https://t.co/PzZxWXwAWx
And here is the German version https://t.co/Nmlt9XLznt https://t.co/kx6fyXVhj8

In an interview, Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel stresses that the ECB is obliged to act on climate change to fulfill its mandate. In spite of rising inflation, there remain concerns about medium-term inflation being too low rather than too high https://t.co/bNUiMO3lBZ https://t.co/DqsbtU6N6H

We assessed banks’ overall capacity to recover from crises. They tend to overestimate their own recovery capacity and underestimate the time they need to implement recovery options. Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/cbgQsV3Hrz https://t.co/k5DuGNpgju

We all gain from global financial stability, says Carolyn Rogers, Secretary General of the Basel Committee @BIS_org. The full benefits of Basel III can only be locked in if we all implement the reforms. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/cbgQsV3Hrz https://t.co/4k2j3Yy5rh
Euro area monthly balance of payments (June 2021) https://t.co/6LwhFYKC9R

Our revised forward guidance is a fundamental step in fulfilling our commitment to 2% inflation, writes Chief Economist Philip R. Lane on #TheECBBlog.

He also discusses the three conditions that should be met before interest rates are raised https://t.co/4bwXA1QqxX https://t.co/QmI0jjBz1M

What’s the case for implementing Basel III according to Carolyn Rogers, Secretary General of the Basel Committee @BIS_org? Was the ECB’s dividend recommendation effective? How do banks manage climate risk? Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/cbgQsV3Hrz https://t.co/aPV0YC0lfR

In the second quarter of 2021, €909 billion worth of bank loans given to households and firms in the euro area had been securitised. Read our press release for more statistics on securitised loans https://t.co/Nw7nwb3Zou https://t.co/JLJJ4oVV2d

Find out in #TheECBPodcast with @GabrielGlockler and host @KatieRanger_ https://t.co/9XURfwTaUW https://t.co/vn1tTt54dj

How have European banks managed credit risk during the pandemic? Are they prepared for climate change? We will discuss these topics and more at the ECB Forum on Banking Supervision this November. Read the full programme now https://t.co/D3ZT3IdUNX https://t.co/bkY7ORLPjm
Euro area securities issues statistics (June 2021) https://t.co/EJmkk4umj3

Banks in the euro area continue to improve their ability to face liquidity disruptions. Their aggregate liquidity coverage ratio, which measures their ability to meet short-term obligations, grew by 17.8% in the past year. Read our press release https://t.co/hwFDiRQEy3 https://t.co/2K0fzLIFRp
Economic Bulletin box: The structural impact of the shift from defined benefits to defined contributions https://t.co/d9ivNcDMQ7
Economic Bulletin box: The heterogeneous economic impact of the pandemic across euro area countries https://t.co/OoH8LiKDdn

Economic Bulletin article: An overview of the ECB’s monetary policy strategy https://t.co/KwGgvn6MAo

Input costs for raw materials and intermediate products have increased in 2021. But the expected upward pressures on consumer goods inflation should not lead to a substantial strengthening in underlying inflation trends in the euro area https://t.co/shAqRXgx6L #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/q5nLJIuFDM

The latest Economic Bulletin is out! The Bulletin presents the economic and monetary information which forms the basis for our policy decisions. Read more  https://t.co/L2uNBASU7g https://t.co/Ip3sPw05VJ

While machine learning methods can help overcome the shortcomings of big data and exploit their full potential, at the moment they should still be considered as complementing standard data and methods rather than replacing them 3/3

These tools are particularly suitable for capturing large shocks and less-direct impacts in a timely manner. This was demonstrated during the crisis, when they provided useful signals about the state of the economy from things like online job ads and newspaper articles 2/3

(THREAD) The coronavirus pandemic has accelerated the trend of international institutions and central banks using big data and machine learning to analyse the business cycle in real time, says the Economic Bulletin https://t.co/s3mOSnCbZg 1/3 #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/BLahQADgJy

Euro area government support helped prevent major disruptions to companies during the coronavirus crisis. It will be important to move to increasingly targeted measures and reduce reliance on support measures as the recovery continues https://t.co/5zjFoyjlc6 #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/BdpO1nLo5r

Job retention schemes have helped sustain wage growth during the pandemic. The strong differences in wage developments across sectors reflect the degree to which they have been affected by the crisis https://t.co/OHtjUfJp3u #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/H8iIPK8SoQ

Households’ tendency to save has peaked during the pandemic. The spike has mostly been involuntary and held in bank deposits, and we do not expect an additional boost to the expected rebound in private consumption in the coming years https://t.co/3YW17xRJqU #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/Z4sdxPZ7it

The pandemic has led to an unprecedented increase in household savings across advanced economies. The large stock of savings accumulated since early 2020 could significantly influence the post-pandemic recovery path https://t.co/t0OhlFR5G5 #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/M7CMrtM4yq

The 2021 stress test results show that the euro area banking system is resilient in the face of adverse economic developments. The report covers 89 euro area banks, and for the first time we released some individual data for medium-sized banks. https://t.co/WnBKerlSFU https://t.co/vdwSlu1pSr
The ECB Survey of Monetary Analysts (SMA) - Aggregate Results (July 2021) https://t.co/ZhJ3UXaU0F

The EBA has published the results for the individual banks participating in the EU-wide stress test. The results include granular data for 38 euro area banks that took part in the exercise. https://t.co/qGw9pHtQB5
Working Paper: A unified framework for CBDC design - remuneration, collateral haircuts and quantity constraints https://t.co/bPvW6XisMW

Financial stability will play a more prominent role in the future, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos in an interview with Handelsblatt. Support is still needed as uncertainty prevails and we need to avoid a cliff edge when the PEPP ends https://t.co/1NdhpCnK2I https://t.co/jKSaWETSlH
Account of the meeting of the Governing Council on the conclusion of the ECB's strategy review 2020-21 held on 7 July 2021 https://t.co/qajHxJ3Aqm
